description.narrative: CDA’s Reflecting on Peace Practice program (RPP) aims to strengthen the way organizations wage peace. The program’s current focus is on how peacebuilding programs can “add up” to societal-level peace, as well as how to strengthen peace program design and evaluation. Detailed in the book, Confronting War: Critical Lessons for Peace Practitioners, RPP’s core insights and contributions to the field include RPP’s Building Blocks Toward Peace and the RPP Matrix, both of which help practitioners design programs to contribute to what RPP calls Peace Writ Large. Further tools and exercises include the RPP Program Reflection Exercise, created to review and improve program logic and planning, including theories of change. The RPP Participant Training Manual, elucidates key RPP findings across program phases, from analysis to implementation and review. Various RPP issue papers explore special topics, from strategies for handling key actors who are “hard to reach,” to the contribution of civil society to peacebuilding processes. Recent working papers explore RPP’s contribution to the evaluation of peacebuilding programs. These materials are available at www.cdacollaborative.org.
